message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Deep Reinforcement Learning for Robotics: A Survey of Real-World Successes
Paper Abstract: Reinforcement learning (RL), particularly its combination with deep neural networks referred to as deep RL (DRL), has shown tremendous promise across a wide range of applications, suggesting its potential for enabling the development of sophisticated robotic behaviors. Robotics problems, however, pose fundamental difficulties for the application of RL, stemming from the complexity and cost of interacting with the physical world. These challenges notwithstanding, recent advances have enabled DRL to succeed at some real-world robotic tasks. However, state-of-the-art DRL solutions’ maturity varies significantly across robotic applications. In this talk, I will review the current progress of DRL in real-world robotic applications based on our recent survey paper (with Tang, Abbatematteo, Hu, Chandra, and Martı́n-Martı́n), with a particular focus on evaluating the real-world successes achieved with DRL in realizing several key robotic competencies, including locomotion, navigation, stationary manipulation, mobile manipulation, human-robot interaction, and multi-robot interaction. The analysis aims to identify the key factors underlying those exciting successes, reveal underexplored areas, and provide an overall characterization of the status of DRL in robotics. I will also highlight several important avenues for future work, emphasizing the need for stable and sample-efficient real-world RL paradigms, holistic approaches for discovering and integrating various competencies to tackle complex long-horizon, open-world tasks, and principled development and evaluation procedures. The talk is designed to offer insights for RL practitioners and roboticists toward harnessing RL’s power to create generally capable real-world robotic systems.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

I've completed the web search for "Robotics". Here's a summary of the key information found:

## Definition and Overview

Robotics is the interdisciplinary study and practice of the design, construction, operation, and use of robots.(no content)A robot is a machine—especially one programmable by a computer—capable of carrying out a complex series of actions automatically.

## Key Components of Robotics

Within mechanical engineering, robotics is the design and construction of the physical structures of robots, while in computer science, robotics focuses on robotic automation algorithms. Robotics typically involves three main aspects:

1. **Mechanical construction** - the physical frame and structure
2. **Electrical components** - systems that power and control the machinery
3. **Software** - programs that determine how the robot performs tasks

## Applications and Types

Robotics has diverse applications including:
- Collaborative robots (Cobots) with applications in commercial fields, robotic research, dispensing, material handling, assembly, finishing, and quality inspection
- Soft robotics, a subfield that concerns the design, control, and fabrication of robots composed of compliant materials, instead of rigid links
- Hexapod robots, which are mechanical vehicles that walk on six legs

The field continues to evolve with innovations in humanoid robots, autonomous systems, and specialized applications across industries.

I've completed the web search for "Robotics". Here's a summary of the key information found:

## Definition and Overview

Robotics is the interdisciplinary study and practice of the design, construction, operation, and use of robots.(no content)A robot is a machine—especially one programmable by a computer—capable of carrying out a complex series of actions automatically.

## Key Components of Robotics

Within mechanical engineering, robotics is the design and construction of the physical structures of robots, while in computer science, robotics focuses on robotic automation algorithms. Robotics typically involves three main aspects:

1. **Mechanical construction** - the physical frame and structure
2. **Electrical components** - systems that power and control the machinery
3. **Software** - programs that determine how the robot performs tasks

## Applications and Types

Robotics has diverse applications including:
- Collaborative robots (Cobots) with applications in commercial fields, robotic research, dispensing, material handling, assembly, finishing, and quality inspection
- Soft robotics, a subfield that concerns the design, control, and fabrication of robots composed of compliant materials, instead of rigid links
- Hexapod robots, which are mechanical vehicles that walk on six legs

The field continues to evolve with innovations in humanoid robots, autonomous systems, and specialized applications across industries.

Web search results for query: "Reinforcement Learning"

Links: [{"title":"Reinforcement learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reinforcement_learning"},{"title":"Reinforcement learning from human feedback - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reinforcement_learning_from_human_feedback"},{"title":"Multi-agent reinforcement learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multi-agent_reinforcement_learning"},{"title":"Self-play (reinforcement learning technique) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Self-play_(reinforcement_learning_technique)"},{"title":"Model-free (reinforcement learning) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Model-free_(reinforcement_learning)"},{"title":"Category:Reinforcement learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Reinforcement_learning"},{"title":"Deep reinforcement learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deep_reinforcement_learning"},{"title":"Q-learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Q-learning"},{"title":"Self-supervised learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Self-supervised_learning"},{"title":"Imitation learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Imitation_learning"}]

## Reinforcement Learning

Reinforcement learning (RL) is concerned with how an intelligent agent should take actions in a dynamic environment in order to maximize a reward signal.(no content)It is one of the three basic machine learning paradigms, alongside supervised learning and unsupervised learning.

### Key Concepts

While supervised learning and unsupervised learning algorithms attempt to discover patterns in labeled and unlabeled data, reinforcement learning involves training an agent through interactions with its environment.(no content)To learn to maximize rewards from these interactions, the agent makes decisions between trying new actions to learn more about the environment (exploration), or using current knowledge of the environment to take the best action (exploitation).

### Applications

Reinforcement learning has been applied successfully to various problems, including energy storage, robot control, photovoltaic generators, backgammon, checkers, Go (AlphaGo), and autonomous driving systems.(no content)Deep reinforcement learning has been used for a diverse set of applications including but not limited to robotics, video games, natural language processing, computer vision, education, transportation, finance and healthcare.

### Subfields and Variants

Several specialized areas have emerged within reinforcement learning:

- **Deep Reinforcement Learning**: Deep reinforcement learning is a subfield of machine learning that combines reinforcement learning and deep learning, incorporating deep learning into the solution to allow agents to make decisions from unstructured input data without manual engineering of the state space.

- **Multi-agent Reinforcement Learning**: Multi-agent reinforcement learning is a sub-field of reinforcement learning that focuses on studying the behavior of multiple learning agents that coexist in a shared environment.

- **Reinforcement Learning from Human Feedback**: Reinforcement learning from human feedback (RLHF) is a technique to align an intelligent agent with human preferences, involving training a reward model to represent preferences, which can then be used to train other models through reinforcement learning.

Based on the search results, here's what I found about Deep Neural Networks:

## Definition and Structure

A network is typically called a deep neural network if it has at least two hidden layers.(no content)The adjective "deep" refers to the use of multiple layers (ranging from three to several hundred or thousands) in the network.

## How They Work

In machine learning, a neural network is a computational model inspired by the structure and functions of biological neural networks, consisting of connected units or nodes called artificial neurons, which loosely model the neurons in the brain.(no content)During the training phase, ANNs learn from labeled training data by iteratively updating their parameters to minimize a defined loss function.

## Applications and Uses

Deep learning focuses on utilizing multilayered neural networks to perform tasks such as classification, regression, and representation learning.(no content)Common deep learning network architectures include fully connected networks, deep belief networks, recurrent neural networks, convolutional neural networks, generative adversarial networks, transformers, and neural radiance fields, which have been applied to fields including computer vision, speech recognition, natural language processing, machine translation, bioinformatics, drug design, and medical image analysis.

## Historical Background

The term deep learning was introduced to the machine learning community by Rina Dechter in 1986, and to artificial neural networks by Igor Aizenberg and colleagues in 2000.

Based on the web search results, here's an overview of robot navigation:

## What is Robot Navigation?

Robot navigation is the robot's ability to determine its own position in its frame of reference and then to plan a path towards some goal location.(no content)To navigate in its environment, a robot or mobility device requires a map of the environment and the ability to interpret that representation.

## Key Components

Robot navigation involves several fundamental components:

- **Localization**: Path planning requires the determination of the robot's current position and a position of a goal location, both within the same frame of reference or coordinates.

- **Mapping**: Some robot navigation systems use simultaneous localization and mapping to generate 3D reconstructions of their surroundings.

## Navigation Methods

There are various approaches to robot navigation:

- **Vision-based Navigation**: Vision-based navigation uses computer vision algorithms and optical sensors, including laser-based range finders and photometric cameras, to extract visual features required for localization.

## What is Robot Navigation?

Robot navigation is the robot's ability to determine its own position in its frame of reference and then to plan a path towards some goal location.(no content)To navigate in its environment, a robot or mobility device requires a map of the environment and the ability to interpret that representation.

## Key Components

Robot navigation involves several fundamental components:

- **Localization**: Path planning requires the determination of the robot's current position and a position of a goal location, both within the same frame of reference or coordinates.

- **Mapping**: Some robot navigation systems use simultaneous localization and mapping to generate 3D reconstructions of their surroundings.

## Navigation Methods

There are various approaches to robot navigation:

- **Vision-based Navigation**: Vision-based navigation uses computer vision algorithms and optical sensors, including laser-based range finders and photometric cameras, to extract visual features required for localization.

- **Guided Navigation**: Guidance can be done in different ways: burying an inductive loop or magnets in the floor, painting lines on the floor, or by placing beacons, markers, bar codes etc. in the environment, and such Automated Guided Vehicles (AGVs) are used in industrial scenarios for transportation tasks.

- **Other Systems**: Autonomous underwater vehicles can be guided by underwater acoustic positioning systems, navigation systems using sonar have also been developed, and robots can also determine their positions using radio navigation.

## Types of Mobile Robots

Mobile robots can be "autonomous" (AMR - autonomous mobile robot) which means they are capable of navigating an uncontrolled environment without the need for physical or electro-mechanical guidance devices.

Mason - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Matthew_T._Mason"},{"title":"Kanguera - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kanguera"},{"title":"Serial manipulator - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Serial_manipulator"},{"title":"Industrial robot - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Industrial_robot"},{"title":"Remote manipulator - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Remote_manipulator"},{"title":"Schoenflies displacement - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Schoenflies_displacement"}]

Based on the search results, here's an overview of robotic manipulation:

## Definition

A definition of robotic manipulation has been provided by Matt Mason as: "manipulation refers to an agent's control of its environment through selective contact".

## Key Components

Robots need to manipulate objects; pick up, modify, destroy, move or otherwise have an effect. The functional end of a robot arm intended to make the effect (whether a hand, or tool) are often referred to as end effectors, while the "arm" is referred to as a manipulator.

## Types of Manipulators

**Serial Manipulators**: Serial manipulators are the most common industrial robots and they are designed as a series of links connected by motor-actuated joints that extend from a base to an end-effector.(no content)Serial robots usually have six joints, because it requires at least six degrees of freedom to place a manipulated object in an arbitrary position and orientation in the workspace of the robot.

**Mobile Manipulators**: A mobile manipulator is a robot system built from a robotic manipulator arm mounted on a mobile platform. A mobile robotic system combines the mobility offered by a mobile platform and dexterity offered by the manipulator.

## Applications

Today, many robotic manipulators, including some with parallel kinematic architecture, are used in industry for applications ranging from the manufacture of electronics to food processing and packaging industry. Additionally, mobile manipulators, either autonomous or remote operated, are used in many areas, such as space exploration, military operations, home care and health care.

Sheridan - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thomas_B._Sheridan"},{"title":"hitchBOT - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/HitchBOT"}]

Based on the search results, here's an overview of Human-Robot Interaction:

## Definition and Scope

Human–robot interaction (HRI) is the study of interactions between humans and robots.(no content)Human–robot interaction is a multidisciplinary field with contributions from human–computer interaction, artificial intelligence, robotics, natural language processing, design, psychology and philosophy.

## Key Research Areas

Generally human–robot interaction prioritizes the safety of humans that interact with potentially dangerous robotics equipment.(no content)The subfield of physical human–robot interaction (pHRI) has largely focused on device design to enable people to safely interact with robotic systems, but is increasingly developing algorithmic approaches in an attempt to support fluent and expressive interactions between humans and robotic systems.

## Technological Advances

Although initially robots in the human–robot interaction field required some human intervention to function, research has expanded this to the extent that fully autonomous systems are now far more common than in the early 2000s. Autonomous systems include from simultaneous localization and mapping systems which provide intelligent robot movement to natural-language processing and natural-language generation systems which allow for natural, human-esque interaction.

## Applications

Goals in HRI range from industrial manufacturing through Cobots, medical technology through rehabilitation, autism intervention, and elder care devices, entertainment, human augmentation.

## Human-Robot Collaboration

Industrial applications of human-robot collaboration involve Collaborative Robots, or cobots, that physically interact with humans in a shared workspace to complete tasks such as collaborative manipulation or object handovers.

Human-Robot Interaction continues to be an active and evolving field with significant research and practical applications across multiple industries.

Links: [{"title":"Deep reinforcement learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deep_reinforcement_learning"},{"title":"Reinforcement learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reinforcement_learning"},{"title":"Multi-agent reinforcement learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multi-agent_learning"},{"title":"Q-learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Q-learning"},{"title":"Fine-tuning (deep learning) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fine-tuning_(deep_learning)"},{"title":"Reinforcement learning from human feedback - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reinforcement_learning_from_human_feedback"},{"title":"Policy gradient method - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Policy_gradient_method"},{"title":"Learning automaton - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Learning_automaton"},{"title":"Machine learning in physics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Machine_learning_in_physics"},{"title":"Learning rate - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Learning_rate"}]

Based on the search results, here's a comprehensive overview of Deep Reinforcement Learning:

## Overview

Deep reinforcement learning (deep RL) is a subfield of machine learning that combines reinforcement learning (RL) and deep learning.(no content)RL considers the problem of a computational agent learning to make decisions by trial and error.(no content)Deep RL incorporates deep learning into the solution, allowing agents to make decisions from unstructured input data without manual engineering of the state space.

## Key Capabilities

Deep RL algorithms are able to take in very large inputs (e.g. every pixel rendered to the screen in a video game) and decide what actions to perform to optimize an objective (e.g. maximizing the game score).

## Applications

Deep reinforcement learning has been used for a diverse set of applications including but not limited to robotics, video games, natural language processing, computer vision, education, transportation, finance and healthcare.

## Major Achievements

In the past decade, deep RL has achieved remarkable results on a range of problems, from single and multiplayer games such as Go, Atari Games, and Dota 2 to robotics. Notable milestones include:
- Beginning around 2013, DeepMind showed impressive learning results using deep RL to play Atari video games, outperforming competing methods on almost all the games and performing at a level comparable or superior to a professional human game tester.
- Deep reinforcement learning reached another milestone in 2015 when AlphaGo, a computer program trained with deep RL to play Go, became the first computer Go program to beat a human professional Go player without handicap on a full-sized 19×19 board.

## Training Approaches

There is a distinction between model-based and model-free reinforcement learning, which refers to whether the algorithm attempts to learn a forward model of the environment dynamics. In model-based deep reinforcement learning algorithms, a forward model of the environment dynamics is estimated, usually by supervised learning using a neural network.

Links: [{"title":"Robot locomotion - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robot_locomotion"},{"title":"Legged robot - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Legged_robot"},{"title":"Bio-inspired robotics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bio-inspired_robotics"},{"title":"Mobile robot - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mobile_robot"},{"title":"Robotics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robotics"},{"title":"Peristaltic robot - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Peristaltic_robot"},{"title":"Whegs - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Whegs"},{"title":"Microbotics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microbotics"},{"title":"Neurorobotics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Neurorobotics"},{"title":"Locomotion - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Locomotion"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about locomotion robots:

## What is Robot Locomotion?

Robot locomotion is the collective name for the various methods that robots use to transport themselves from place to place.(no content)A mobile robot is an automatic machine that is capable of locomotion.

## Types of Robot Locomotion

Robots use several different locomotion methods:

**Wheeled Robots**: Wheeled robots are typically quite energy efficient and simple to control. However, other forms of locomotion may be more appropriate for a number of reasons, for example traversing rough terrain, as well as moving and interacting in human environments.

**Legged Robots**: Legged robots are a type of mobile robot which use articulated limbs, such as leg mechanisms, to provide locomotion. They are more versatile than wheeled robots and can traverse many different terrains, though these advantages require increased complexity and power consumption.

**Walking Robots**: Walking robots simulate human or animal gait, as a replacement for wheeled motion. Different types include:
- Bipedal or two-legged robots exhibit bipedal motion.
- Quadrupedal or four-legged robots exhibit quadrupedal motion. They benefit from increased stability over bipedal robots, especially during movement.
- Hexapod robots are based on insect locomotion, most popularly the cockroach and stick insect.

**Snake Robots**: Several snake robots have been successfully developed. Mimicking the way real snakes move, these robots can navigate very confined spaces, meaning they may one day be used to search for people trapped in collapsed buildings.

**Peristaltic Robots**: A peristaltic robot, also known as a worm-bot, is a robot that uses peristaltic locomotion to move, mimicking the movement of earthworms.

**Whegs**: Whegs (wheel-legs or wing-legs) are mechanisms for robot locomotion. Whegs use a strategy of locomotion that combines the simplicity of the wheel with the obstacle-clearing advantages of the foot.

## Applications and Goals

A major goal in this field is in developing capabilities for robots to autonomously decide how, when, and where to move.

I've successfully searched Wikipedia for "Human Robot Interaction" and found comprehensive results. Here's what I found:

## Key Information from Wikipedia

**Definition and Scope:**
Human–robot interaction (HRI) is the study of interactions between humans and robots.(no content)Human–robot interaction is a multidisciplinary field with contributions from human–computer interaction, artificial intelligence, robotics, natural language processing, design, psychology and philosophy.

**Safety Focus:**
Human–robot interaction prioritizes the safety of humans that interact with potentially dangerous robotics equipment.

**Research Development:**
Although initially robots in the human–robot interaction field required some human intervention to function, research has expanded this to the extent that fully autonomous systems are now far more common than in the early 2000s. Autonomous systems include from simultaneous localization and mapping systems which provide intelligent robot movement to natural-language processing systems which allow for natural, human-esque interaction.

**Applications:**
Goals in HRI range from industrial manufacturing through Cobots, medical technology through rehabilitation, autism intervention, and elder care devices, entertainment, human augmentation.

The search also returned related Wikipedia articles on human-robot collaboration, humanoid robots, social robots, and cobots, which expand on different aspects of human-robot interaction.
